company.name: Sunbelt Lending Services, Inc.
company.address: 300 South Park Place Blvd., Suite 150, Clearwater, Florida 33759
company.business_description: Sunbelt is a mortgage company and financial institution that collects nonpublic personal information from customers including names, social security numbers, credit histories, bank account numbers, and income tax returns. It operates through loan officers located throughout Florida, including offices affiliated with Coldwell Banker Residential Real Estate, Inc. as a wholly-owned subsidiary of Cendant Mortgage Corporation.

case_info.legal_authority: Section 5(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. ยง 45(a)(1); Title V of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, 15 U.S.C. ยง 6801 et seq.

complaint.factual_background: Sunbelt Lending Services, a Florida-based mortgage company, collected sensitive customer information including social security numbers, credit histories, and bank account numbers through loan officers across Florida. From May 2003 until at least April 2004, the company failed to implement reasonable security policies and procedures to protect this information, including failing to assess risks, provide employee training, oversee remote loan officers, or require service providers to safeguard customer data. Additionally, from July 2001 until at least April 2004, Sunbelt failed to provide required privacy notices to its online customers.

counts.title: Violations of the Safeguards Rule
counts.representation: As a financial institution subject to the Safeguards Rule, respondent was required to develop a comprehensive written information security program with reasonable administrative, technical, and physical safeguards to protect customer information
counts.fact: Respondent failed to identify reasonably foreseeable risks to customer information; failed to implement information safeguards to control risks and regularly test and monitor them; failed to develop, implement, and maintain a comprehensive written information security program; failed to oversee service providers and require them by contract to implement safeguards; and failed to designate one or more employees to coordinate the information security program
counts.conclusion: A violation of the Safeguards Rule constitutes an unfair or deceptive act or practice in violation of Section 5(a)(1) of the FTC Act.

counts.title: Violations of the Privacy Rule
counts.representation: As a financial institution subject to the Privacy Rule, respondent was required to provide customers with clear and conspicuous notices, both when the customer relationship is formed and annually for the duration of the customer relationship, that accurately reflect the financial institution's privacy policies and practices
counts.fact: From the Rule's effective date until at least April 2004, respondent failed to provide its online customers with the notices required by the Privacy Rule
counts.conclusion: A violation of the Privacy Rule constitutes an unfair or deceptive act or practice in violation of Section 5(a)(1) of the FTC Act.

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Violating Safeguards Rule and Privacy Rule
provisions.summary: Respondent must not violate the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act's Safeguards Rule or Privacy Rule.

requirements.description: Must not violate the GLB Act's Safeguards Rule or Privacy Rule
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS ORDERED that respondent shall not, directly or through any corporation, subsidiary, division, Web site, or other device, violate any provision of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act's ("GLB Act") Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule ("Safeguards Rule"), 16 C.F.R. Part 314, or the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act's Privacy of Consumer Financial Information Rule ("Privacy Rule"), 16 C.F.R. Part 313.

provisions.title: Third-Party Security Assessments
provisions.summary: Respondent must obtain biennial security assessments from qualified third-party professionals for ten years, starting within 180 days after service of the order.

requirements.quoted_text: IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that, in connection with its compliance with the Safeguards Rule, respondent shall obtain an assessment and report (an "Assessment") from a qualified, objective, independent third-party professional, using procedures and standards generally accepted in the profession, within one hundred and eighty (180) days after service of the order, and biennially thereafter for ten (10) years after service of the order

requirements.description: Assessment must set forth specific administrative, technical, and physical safeguards implemented
requirements.quoted_text: sets forth the specific administrative, technical, and physical safeguards that respondent has implemented and maintained during the reporting period

requirements.description: Assessment must explain how safeguards are appropriate to respondent's size, complexity, nature and scope of activities, and sensitivity of information
requirements.quoted_text: explains how such safeguards are appropriate to respondent's size and complexity, the nature and scope of respondent's activities, and the sensitivity of the nonpublic personal information collected from or about consumers

requirements.description: Assessment must explain how safeguards meet or exceed Safeguards Rule requirements
requirements.quoted_text: explains how such safeguards meet or exceed the protections required by the Safeguards Rule

requirements.description: Assessment must certify that security program is operating effectively
requirements.quoted_text: certifies that respondent's security program is operating with sufficient effectiveness to provide reasonable assurance that the security, confidentiality, and integrity of nonpublic personal information is protected and, for biennial reports, has so operated throughout the reporting period

requirements.description: Provide first Assessment and supporting materials to FTC
requirements.quoted_text: Respondent shall provide the first Assessment, as well as all plans, reports, studies, reviews, audits, audit trails, policies, training materials, and assessments, whether prepared by or on behalf of respondent, relied upon to prepare such Assessment to the Associate Director for Enforcement, Bureau of Consumer Protection, Federal Trade Commission, Washington, D.C. 20580, within ten (10) days after the Assessment has been prepared.

requirements.description: Retain subsequent biennial Assessments until order termination and supporting materials for 3 years
requirements.quoted_text: Respondent shall retain all subsequent biennial Assessments until the order is terminated and shall retain all materials relied upon in preparing each such Assessment, as listed above, for a period of three (3) years after the date of preparation of such Assessment.

requirements.description: Provide subsequent Assessments and materials to FTC upon request
requirements.quoted_text: Respondent shall provide such subsequent Assessments and related materials to the Associate Director of Enforcement within ten (10) days of request.

provisions.title: Acknowledgment of Order
provisions.summary: Respondent must deliver a copy of this order to current and future personnel with supervisory responsibilities.

requirements.description: Deliver order to current principals, officers, directors, managers, and supervisory employees
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that respondent shall deliver a copy of this order to all current and future principals, officers, directors, and managers, and to all current and future employees, agents, and representatives having supervisory responsibilities with respect to the subject matter of this order. Respondent shall deliver this order to such current personnel within thirty (30) days after the date of service of this order

requirements.description: Deliver order to future personnel with supervisory responsibilities
requirements.quoted_text: Respondent shall deliver this order to all current and future principals, officers, directors, and managers, and to all current and future employees, agents, and representatives having supervisory responsibilities with respect to the subject matter of this order...and to such future personnel within thirty (30) days after the person assumes such position or responsibilities.

provisions.title: Notice of Corporate Changes
provisions.summary: Respondent must notify the Commission at least 30 days prior to any corporate change that may affect compliance obligations.

requirements.description: Notify Commission 30 days prior to corporate changes affecting compliance
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that respondent shall notify the Commission at least thirty (30) days prior to any change in the corporation that may affect compliance obligations arising under this order, including, but not limited to, a dissolution, assignment, sale, merger, or other action that would result in the emergence of a successor corporation; the creation or dissolution of a subsidiary, parent, or affiliate that engages in any acts or practices subject to this order; the proposed filing of a bankruptcy petition; or a change in the corporate name or address.

requirements.description: Notify Commission as soon as practicable for changes learned less than 30 days in advance
requirements.quoted_text: Provided, however, that, with respect to any proposed change in the corporation about which respondent learns less than thirty (30) days prior to the date such action is to take place, respondent shall notify the Commission as soon as is practicable after obtaining such knowledge.

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Respondent must file a written compliance report with the Commission within 180 days and at other times as required.

requirements.description: File initial compliance report including copy of first Assessment
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that respondent shall within one hundred eighty (180) days after service of this order, and at such other times as the Federal Trade Commission may require, file with the Commission a report, in writing, setting forth in detail the manner and form in which it has complied with this order. This report shall include a copy of the initial biennial Assessment required by Part II of this order.

provisions.title: Order Duration and Termination
provisions.summary: This order will terminate on January 3, 2025, or 20 years from the most recent date of a federal court complaint alleging order violation, whichever is later.

requirements.description: Order terminates on specified date or 20 years from most recent complaint
requirements.quoted_text: This order will terminate on January 3, 2025, or twenty (20) years from the most recent date that the United States or the Federal Trade Commission files a complaint (with or without an accompanying consent decree) in federal court alleging any violation of the order, whichever comes later

duration.termination_text: This order will terminate on January 3, 2025, or twenty (20) years from the most recent date that the United States or the Federal Trade Commission files a complaint (with or without an accompanying consent decree) in federal court alleging any violation of the order, whichever comes later; provided, however, that the filing of such a complaint will not affect the duration of: A. Any Part in this order that terminates in less than twenty (20) years; B. This order's application to any respondent that is not named as a defendant in such complaint; and C. This order if such complaint is filed after the order has terminated pursuant to this Part.
